tit.e: Kokyu (an imperial harem and empress's residence)
tit.cmt: 用語集には(empress's residence)となっているため修正しました。

sen.j: 後宮（こうきゅう）とは、国王や皇帝などの后妃が住まう場所。
sen.e: Kokyu palace was designated by the king or emperor as the living quarters for the queen or empress.
Kokyu palace was where the empress of the king or emperor lived.
sen.cmt: designated ～の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: Kokyu palace was where the empress of the king or emperor lived.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 日本では、平安京内裏の七殿五舎が該当する。
sen.e: In Japan, the Shichidengosha (a palace) inside Heian-kyo dairi (imperial palace of the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) was an example of a Kokyu palace.
In Japan, the Shichidengosha (a palace) located inside of Heian-kyo dairi (imperial palace of the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) was an example of a Kokyu palace.
sen.cmt: inside→located inside of としました。
sen.e: In Japan, the Shichidengosha (a palace) located inside of Heian-kyo dairi (imperial palace of the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) was an example of a Kokyu palace.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 一般的に、後宮は男子禁制というイメージがあるが、日本では必ずしもそうではなかった。
sen.e: In general and through out history a kingdoms subjects maintained the concept that all men were barred from a 'Kokyu Palace'; yet, that image was not applied in all Japanese Kokyu palace situations.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In general and through out history a kingdoms subjects maintained the concept that all men were barred from a 'Kokyu Palace'; yet, that image was not applied in all Japanese Kokyu palace situations.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: In general and through out history a kingdoms subjects maintained the concept that all men were barred from a 'Kokyu Palace'; yet, that image was not applied in all Japanese Kokyu palace situations.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 平安時代中期に書かれた『源氏物語』を読めば分かるように家族や親しい人間（貴族）は、頻繁に出入りしていたこともあった。
sen.e: For example, a book written in the middle Heian period, "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji), illustrated the presence of male family members and close male acquaintances (nobles, aristocrats) frequently visiting ladies of the court in Kokyu palace.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For example, a book written in the middle Heian period, "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji), illustrated the presence of male family members and close male acquaintances (nobles, aristocrats) frequently visiting ladies of the court in Kokyu palace.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: For example, a book written in the middle Heian period, "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji), illustrated the presence of male family members and close male acquaintances (nobles, aristocrats) frequently visiting ladies of the court in Kokyu palace.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: ただし江戸城大奥は、完全な男性禁制の場であり、火事など緊急時以外の男性の出入りは厳しく制限された。
sen.e: However, the Ooku of Edo castle (the inner palace of Edo Castle) was completely barred to all men, except incase of an emergency, such as fire, male visitors were extremely limited.

However, the O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants reside) of Edo castle was completely closed to all men and, except in case of an emergency, such as fire, male visitors were extremely limited.
sen.cmt: 「大奥」を用語集のものに修正、banned→closed、except→and, except、incase→in case, に修正しました。
sen.e: However, the O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants reside) of Edo castle was completely closed to all men and, except in case of an emergency, such as fire, male visitors were extremely limited.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 男子禁制をとっているのはオスマン帝国などのイスラム諸王朝や中国などであった。
sen.e: Still, there were Kokyu palaces forbidden to male admittance; consider the Islamic dynasties (such as Ottoman Empire), and Chinese dynasties.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Still, the Kokyu palaces in the Islamic dynasties such as Ottoman Empire and Chinese dynasties were forbidden to men's admittance.
sen.cmt: 文章の前後を変え、male→men'sに修正しました。
sen.e: Still, the Kokyu palaces in the Islamic dynasties such as Ottoman Empire and Chinese dynasties were forbidden to men's admittance.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 去勢された宦官が、家政一般にあたった。
sen.e: In the Kokyu palaces castrated eunuchs managed, and were in service for the general household affaires within the palaces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The castrated eunuches managed a general household affaires.
sen.cmt: eunuchs→eunuchesに修正、and were in service for、within the palaces の部分を除きました。
sen.e: The castrated eunuches managed a general household affaires.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これにたいして日本では宦官は置かれずに宮人とも呼ばれる女官が発達して女性達によって秩序が維持された。
sen.e: In contrast, Japan did not engage the efforts of the eunuch class; instead a lady of the court class was developed, called Kyujin (court lady), to maintain the internal order of the Kokyu palaces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In contrast, the court ladies, also called Kyujin, were developed to maintain the internal order of the Kokyu palaces instead of the castrated eunuches in Japan.
sen.cmt: Japan～eunuch classを除き、「女官」＝court ladyを主語として文を修正、文の最後にinstead of～を補足しました。
sen.e: In contrast, the court ladies, also called Kyujin, were developed to maintain the internal order of the Kokyu palaces instead of the castrated eunuches in Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 平安時代には女房と呼ばれる高級女官が優れた宮廷文学（『源氏物語』もその一つ）を生み出した事はよく知られている。
sen.e: During the Heian period high ranking court ladies, called nyobo (court ladies), created an excellent form of court literature [an example was "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji)], this is a universally accepted fact.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is well known that during the Heian period high ranking court ladies, called nyobo (court ladies), created an excellent form of court literature (for example, "Genji Monogatari" [The Tale of Genji]).
sen.cmt: this is～fact→It is well know～, an example→for example としました。括弧([])を逆に修正しました。
sen.e: It is well known that during the Heian period high ranking court ladies, called nyobo (court ladies), created an excellent form of court literature (for example, "Genji Monogatari" [The Tale of Genji]).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、後宮を意味するハレム（harem）は、オスマン帝国の後宮がそう呼ばれていたところからきている。
sen.e: Additionally, the harem referenced in the Kokyu palace is based upon the Ottoman Empire model; and subsequently the Kokyu palace was called Harem.
Additionally, the harem signified the Kokyu palace is based upon the Ottoman Empire which Kokyu palace was called harem.
sen.cmt: referenced→signified, model～subsequently→which に修正しました。
sen.e: Additionally, the harem signified the Kokyu palace is based upon the Ottoman Empire which Kokyu palace was called harem.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 中国で後宮とは宮廷内で天子が家庭生活を営む場所であり、また皇后以下、妃嬪が暮らす場所でもあった。
sen.e: The Kokyu palaces of the Imperial court in China functioned as a palace retreat for the emperor, his empress and family, with the time spent restricted to the hihin (princess, noble's concubine, and court ladies) in the shared living environment.

The Kokyu palaces of the Imperial court in China functioned as a place to have a domestic life for the emperor, and to live for his empress and the hihin (princess, noble's concubine, and court ladies) in the shared living environment.
sen.cmt: palace retreat→place to have a domestic life に修正、and to liveを挿入、with～restricted toを除きました。
sen.e: The Kokyu palaces of the Imperial court in China functioned as a place to have a domestic life for the emperor, and to live for his empress and the hihin (princess, noble's concubine, and court ladies) in the shared living environment.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: そのため后妃のこと自体を後宮ということがある。
sen.e: This would be the rationale, in some case, for the Empress herself to be called Kokyu.
Therefore, in some case, the Empress herself to be called Kokyu.
sen.cmt: This would be the rationale→Thereforeに修正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, in some case, the Empress herself to be called Kokyu.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: その他、後宮には多くの女官や宦官たちが暮らし、後宮内での職務に従事した。
sen.e: Additionally, most court ladies and the attending eunuchs lived in Kokyu palaces and engaged in the routine work duties of a Kokyu palace.
Additionally, most court ladies and the attending eunuchs lived in Kokyu palaces and engaged in the routine work duties of a Kokyu palace.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Additionally, most court ladies and the attending eunuchs lived in Kokyu palaces and engaged in the routine work duties of a Kokyu palace.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 唐代の制度では、後宮の職官は、内官・宮官・内侍省の3部門で構成されていた。
sen.e: Under the Tang Dynasty regulations, rankings and service titles in a Kokyu palace were organized into three departments: Naikan (内官), Kyukan (宮官), and Naishi Sho (内侍省).
Under the Tang Dynasty system, rankings and service titles in a Kokyu palace were organized into three departments: Naikan, Kyukan, and Naishi Sho.
sen.cmt: regulations→systemに修正、括弧内の日本語は不要と判断し除きました。
sen.e: Under the Tang Dynasty system, rankings and service titles in a Kokyu palace were organized into three departments: Naikan, Kyukan, and Naishi Sho.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 内官とは妃妾のことである。
sen.e: Naikan (内官) was used in reference to a princess and a mistress.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Naikan means a princess and a mistress.
sen.cmt: 括弧内の日本語は不要と判断し除きました。was～to→meansに修正しました。
sen.e: Naikan means a princess and a mistress.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 四夫人（貴妃、淑妃、徳妃、賢妃。正一品）。
sen.e: There were four sub-ranks within this rank: First, there were four wives (four ladies who were the consort of the emperor) [Guifei (貴妃), Shufei (淑妃), Defei (德妃), and Xianfei (賢妃): First grade ranking].
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 九嬪（昭儀、昭容、昭媛、修儀、修容、修媛、充儀、充容、充媛。正二品）。
sen.e: Second, there were nine mistresses [Zhaoyi (昭儀), Zhaorong (昭容), Zhaoyuan (昭媛), Xiuyi (修儀), Xiurong(修容), Xiuyuan (修媛), Chongyi(充儀), Chongrong(充容), and Chongyuan (充媛): Second grade ranking].
Second, there were nine mistresses (Zhaoyi [昭儀], Zhaorong [昭容], Zhaoyuan [昭媛], Xiuyi [修儀], Xiurong [修容], Xiuyuan [修媛], Chongyi [充儀], Chongrong [充容], and Chongyuan [充媛]: Second grade ranking).

sen.e: Third, there were twenty-seven seihu (a court lady) [nine Jieyus (婕妤), nine Beautiful Ladies (美人), and nine Talented Ladies (才人): Third to fifth grade ranking].

sen.j: 八十一御妻（宝林、御女、采女。正六品～正八品）を指す。
sen.e: Fourth, there were eighty-one mime (the wife of a person holding high status) [27 Baolin (保林), 27 Imperial Woman (御女), and 29 Cainus (采女): Sixth to eighth grade ranking].
Fourth, there were eighty-one mime (the wife of a person holding high status) (27 Baolin [保林], 27 Imperial Woman [御女], and 29 Cainus [采女]: Sixth to eighth grade ranking).

sen.j: 正六品以下が宮官であり、宮中内の職務に携わる女官たちのことである。
sen.e: Lower than a sixth grade ranking, was the Kyukan; this Kyukan was a court lady who engaged in job duties at Kokyu palace
Lower than a sixth grade ranking were the Kyukan, who were the court ladies engaged in job duties at Kokyu palace.

sen.j: 尚宮（総務的な仕事）・尚儀（礼楽に携わる）・尚服（衣服に携わる）・尚食（食事に携わる）・尚寝（居住空間に携わる）・尚功（工芸に携わる）の六尚に分けられて職務に従事した。
sen.e: A Kyukan was further divided into six job titles (六尚, "liu-shang" in Chinese) and the pursuant job duties: Shang-kung (尚宮, Services related to General affairs): Shangyi (尚儀, Services related to Manner & Etiquette and Music): Shang-fu (尚服, Services related to Clothing): Shang-shih (尚食, Services related to Foods and Beverages): Shang-chin (尚寝, Services related to Housing and Living): Shang-kung (尚功, Services related to Arts and Crafts).

sen.j: 李氏朝鮮における内官は、『経国大典』によると嬪（、ピン、正一品）・貴人（、クィイン、従一品）・昭儀（、ソイ、正二品）・淑儀（、スギ、従二品）・昭容（、ソヨン、正三品）・淑容（、スギョン、従三品）・昭媛（、ソウォン、正四品）・淑媛（、スグォン、従四品）などであった。
sen.e: According to Keikoku Taiten ("Gyeongguk daejeon" in Korean, a Complete Code of Laws), naikan (a government official who resides in Kyoto) in the Yi Dynasty of Korea would be organized in the following way: Pin (嬪, a first grade ranking): Kui-in (貴人, the associated first grade ranking): Soi (昭儀, a second grade ranking): Sugi (淑儀, the associated second grade ranking): Soyon (昭容, a third grade ranking): Sugyon (淑容, the associated third grade ranking): Sowon (昭媛, a forth grade ranking): Suguon (淑媛, the associated forth grade ranking).

sen.e: Nygo: Originally a nyogo referred to another name for Hin (a mistress); but, this term evolved into a position of one in pursuit of the rank of an empress and chugu; therefore, a lady who planed to become an empress or a chugu, would become a nygo first, according to custom.
